content.question:
The following graphs show the sampling distributions for two different point estimators, <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></math> and <math alttext="W" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></math>, of the same population parameter.

Which of the following statements is true?

choices.label: Both <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></math> and <math alttext="W" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></math> are unbiased.
Both <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></math> and <math alttext="W" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></math> are biased.
<math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></math> is biased, and <math alttext="W" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></math> is unbiased.
<math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></math> is unbiased, and <math alttext="W" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></math> is biased.
The assessment of bias is not possible, because the sampling distributions display too much variability.

content.answer: <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></math> is biased, and <math alttext="W" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></math> is unbiased.

skill.text: Skill 4.B: Interpret statistical calculations and findings to assign meaning or assess a claim.
